title: [regression] .mean() for half tensors no longer gives correct result even if result is representable in fp16
body_html:
import torch
x = torch.ones(65520, device='cuda', dtype=torch.float16)
x.mean()

used to produce tensor(1., dtype=torch.float16, device='cuda:0') around the end of May, now it is
tensor(nan, device='cuda:0', dtype=torch.float16)
Two reasons: mean was moved to ATen and thus no longer uses fused THC kernels for this
https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/aten/src/ATen/native/ReduceOps.cpp#L96-L109 (that alone would lead to result being inf), and long numel is apparently being cast to half somewhere in TensorIterator div_, thus leading to nan answer.
Our fault for not adding the tests at the time @mruberry fixed it.

body:
```
import torch
x = torch.ones(65520, device='cuda', dtype=torch.float16)
x.mean()
```
used to produce `tensor(1., dtype=torch.float16, device='cuda:0')` around the end of May, now it is 
`tensor(nan, device='cuda:0', dtype=torch.float16)`
Two reasons: mean was moved to ATen and thus no longer uses fused THC kernels for this
https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/aten/src/ATen/native/ReduceOps.cpp#L96-L109 (that alone would lead to result being `inf`), and long `numel` is apparently being cast to half somewhere in TensorIterator `div_`, thus leading to `nan` answer.
Our fault for not adding the tests at the time @mruberry fixed it.
